change.item:
$Log: ml.xml,v $ Revision 1.4 2004/12/14 19:42:20 packel added entry/sense ids; fixed bad empty tags
Revision 1.3 2004/12/03 20:11:37 packel corrected some duplicate keys caused by fixing the compound verbs
Revision 1.2 2004/12/02 23:29:11 packel added key attributes to compound verb entries
Revision 1.1 2004/11/22 17:07:40 packel converted to P4/XML
Revision 1.20 2004/10/18 18:17:47 packel added div0s; changed orth ʼa)da/mas,ʼ to a)da/mas
Revision 1.19 2004/10/07 14:18:11 packel removed *s in entry keys
Revision 1.18 2004/10/05 21:34:13 packel Aligned dictionary entries with the LSJ.
Revision 1.17 2004/09/08 15:49:42 packel Changed doctype to TEI P4
Revision 1.16 2004/09/01 15:44:25 packel Fixed thirty-odd words that had multiple entries but no number afterward to differentiate the entries (e.g., si=gma, si=gma is now si=gma1, si=gma2).
Revision 1.15 2004/06/15 19:31:34 lcerrato changed nothwithstanding to notwithstanding
Revision 1.14 2003/02/04 21:21:51 lcerrato fixed typo kuma entry swoln to swollen
Revision 1.13 2001/12/05 15:15:58 gcrane shifted the lemma for "pa/nth" to be "pa/nth|"
Revision 1.12 2001/04/20 21:58:57 dasmith Added funder.
Revision 1.11 2001/04/05 18:26:02 lcerrato added trans tags to noeo^ entry where missing
Revision 1.10 2000/10/06 23:20:04 dasmith Tagged inflectional info as Greek.
Revision 1.9 2000/10/06 21:44:13 dasmith Added author and ISBN to head. Use new DTD subset. Explicitly tag lemmata and cross references as Greek.
Revision 1.8 2000/03/04 20:25:11 dasmith Standardized language IDs. Added key attribute to entry.
Revision 1.7 1998/08/24 19:15:31 jrydberg finished trans tags and added new prep. defs.
Revision 1.6 1998/08/20 17:12:45 jrydberg Included greek words within trans tags where appropriate
Revision 1.5 1998/08/19 20:50:08 jrydberg Replaced all "(trans) or (/trans)" with " or "
Revision 1.4 1998/08/19 18:23:58 jrydberg Corrected trans tagging for short defs. through a)mfote/rwqen.
Revision 1.3 1998/08/17 20:24:43 jrydberg *** empty log message ***
Revision 1.2 1998/08/17 19:38:25 jrydberg Updated entry for *)agamemno/neos
Revision 1.1 1998/08/14 15:38:33 textgod Added to repository.

div1.head: ὠβάζω
div1.sense: to divide the people into ὠβαί, Plut.

div1.head: ὠβά
div1.sense: in Laconia, a subdivision of the Spartan φυλαί (clans), Plut.

div1.head: Ὠγυγία
div1.sense: Ogygia, a mythical island in the Mediterranean, the abode of Calypso, Od.

div1.head: Ὠγύγιος
div1.sense: Ogygian, of or from Ogyges, an Attic king of mythical times; hence generally primeval, primal, Hes., Pind.; τὰς ὠγ. Θήβας, τὰς ὠγ. Ἀθήνας Aesch.

div1.head: ᾨδεῖον
div1.sense: the Odeum, a public building, erected by Pericles for musical performances, also used as a lawcourt, Ar., Plut.

div1.head: ὧδε
div1.sense: demonstr. adv. of ὅδε·

of Manner, in this wise, so, thus, and (more strongly) so very, so exceedingly, Hom., etc.:— ὧδε is answered by ὡς, so . . , as . . , Hom.; followed by a relat., τίς ὧδε τλησικάρδιος, ὅτῳ . . ; Aesch.; ὧδέ πως somehow so, Xen., etc.
of Condition, πρόμολʼ ὧδε come forth just as thou art, at once, Hom.
of something following, thus, as follows, Hom.; ὧδʼ ἠμείψατο Soph.
c. gen., ὧδε γένους thus off for family, Eur.
of Place, hither, here, Soph., Theocr.

div1.head: ᾠδή
div1.etym: contr. for ἀοιδή as ᾄδω for ἀείδω
div1.sense: a song, lay, ode, Hhymn., Soph., Eur.; pl. lyric poetry, Plat.
song, singing, Plut.

div1.head: ᾠδικός
div1.sense: fond of singing, vocal, musical, Luc. adv. -κῶς, Ar.

div1.head: ὠδίνω
div1.sense: to have the pains or throes of childbirth, to be in travail or labour, Il., Plat., etc.
c. acc. to be in travail of a child, to bring forth, Eur.
metaph. of any great pain, to be in travail or anguish, Od., Eur.: to work hard, to travail, of bees, Anth.:—of the mind, ὥστε μʼ ὠδίνειν τί φῄς so that I am in an agony as to what you mean, Soph.
c. acc. to be in travail with a thing, c. acc., Soph., Anth.

div1.head: ὡδί
div1.sense: Attic stronger form of ὧδε, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: ὠδίς
div1.sense: the pangs or throes of labour, travail-pains, Il.; ἐν μόναις ὠδῖσιν at a single birth, Pind.; ἐν ὠδίνων ἀνάγκαις Eur.; in sg. travail-pain, anguish, Pind., Soph.
in sg., also, the fruit of travail or labour, a birth, child, Aesch., Eur.; ἄπτερον ὠδῖνα τέκνων, of young birds, Eur.
metaph. any travail, anguish, Aesch.; also in pl., of love, pangs, Soph., Plat.

div1.head: ᾠδοποιός
div1.sense: making songs or odes, Theocr.

div1.head: ᾠδός
div1.sense: a singer, Eur., Plat.

div1.head: ὤεον
div1.sense: an egg, Simon.

div1.head: ὠή
div1.sense: a cry or call, ho there! lat. heus, Aesch., etc.

div1.head: ὠθέω
div1.sense: to thrust, push, shove, force onwards or away, λᾶαν ἄνω ὤθεσκε he kept pushing it upwards, Od.; ἀπʼ ὀφθαλμῶν νέφος ὦσεν Ἀθήνη Il.; ἐκ μηροῦ δόρυ ὦσε he forced the spear from the thigh, Il.; ὦσαί τινα ἀφʼ ἵππων Il.; ὦσαι ἑαυτὸν ἐς τὸ πῦρ to rush into the fire, Hdt.; so, ὠθ. τινὰ ἐπὶ κεφαλήν to throw him headlong down, Plat.; κατὰ πετρῶν Eur.; ὦσαι τὴν θύραν to force the door, Ar.
to push or force back in battle, Il.
to thrust out, banish, Trag.; ὦσαί τινα φυγάδα Plat.; ὠθ. τινα ἄθαπτον Soph.
metaph., ὠθ. τὰ πρήγματα to push matters on, hurry them, Hdt.
absol., ὦσα παρέξ pushed off from land, Od.; ὤθει βιαίως Eur.

Mid., mostly in aor1, to thrust or push from oneself, push or force back, repulse, esp. in battle, τείχεος ἂψ ὤσασθαι Il.; ὤσασθαι προτὶ Ἴλιον, προτὶ ἄστυ Il.; ὤσασθαι τὴν ἵππον Hdt.; ὠσαμένων τὸ κέρας Thuc.
Pass. to be thrust on, to fall violently, ἐπὶ κεφαλήν Hdt.; πρὸς βίαν Eur.
to force oneʼs way, Xen., Plat.: to crowd on, throng, like ὠστίζομαι, Xen.

div1.head: ὠθίζω
div1.sense: Mid., like ὠστίζομαι, to push against one another, justle, struggle, Luc.:—metaph. to wrangle, Hdt.

div1.head: ὠθισμός
div1.sense: a thrusting, pushing, ὠθ. ἀσπίδων, of shield against shield, Thuc.
(from Pass.) a justling, struggling, of combatants in a melee, Hdt., Xen.:— metaph., ὠθισμὸς λόγων a hot dispute, Hdt.

div1.head: ὦκα
div1.sense: quickly, swiftly, fast, Hom.; strengthd., μάλʼ ὦκα, ὦκα μάλʼ Hom.
of Time, ὦκα ἔπειτα immediately thereafter, Hom.

div1.head: Ὠκεανίνη
div1.sense: daughter of Ocean, Hes.

div1.head: Ὠκεανίς
div1.sense: fem. adj. of or from ocean, αὖραι Pind.

div1.head: Ὠκεανῖτις
div1.sense: = ὠκεᾰνίς, Anth.
ἡ ὠκ, (sub. γῆ) the shore of ocean, Strab.

div1.head: Ὠκεανόνδε
div1.sense: to Ocean, Hhymn.

div1.head: Ὠκεανός
div1.sense: Oceanus, son of Uranus and Gaia, Hes.: wedded to Tethys, sire of Thetis, Il.—Homerʼs Oceanus is a great River (Ὠκεανὸς ποταμός) , which compasses the earthʼs disc, returning into itself (ἀψόρροος) .
in later times, Ocean remained as the name of the great Outward Sea, opp. to the Inward or Mediterranean (θάλασσα, πόντος) , Hdt., Pind., etc.

div1.head: ὤκιστα
div1.sense: mostly swiftly, Od.

div1.head: ὠκύαλος
div1.sense: sea-swift, speeding oʼer the sea, of a ship, Hom., Soph.

div1.head: ὠκυβόλος
div1.sense: quick-shooting, quick-striking, of the bow, Soph.; of arrows, Anth.

div1.head: ὠκυδήκτωρ
div1.sense: sharp-biting, Anth.

div1.head: ὠκυδίδακτος
div1.sense: quickly taught, Anth.

div1.head: ὠκυδίνητος
div1.sense: quick-whirling, Pind.

div1.head: ὠκύδρομος
div1.sense: swift-running, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: ὠκυεπής
div1.sense: quick-speaking, Anth.

div1.head: ὠκύθοος
div1.sense: swift-running, Eur.

div1.head: ὠκυμάχος
div1.sense: quick to fight, Anth.

div1.head: ὠκύμορος
div1.sense: quickly-dying, dying early, of Achilles, Il.; ὠκυμορώτατος ἄλλων Il.
act. bringing a quick or early death, Hom.

div1.head: ὠκυπέτης
div1.sense: swift-flying, swift-running, Il., Hes.; metaph., ὠκ. μόρος Soph.

div1.head: ὠκύποινος
div1.sense: quickly-avenged, Aesch.

div1.head: ὠκύπομπος
div1.sense: quick-sending, conveying rapidly, Eur.

div1.head: ὠκύπορος
div1.sense: quick-going, of ships, Il.: of streams, swift-flowing, Aesch.

div1.head: ὠκύπος
div1.etym: rare poet. collat. form of ὠκύπους, Anth.

div1.head: ὠκύπους
div1.sense: swift-footed, of horses, Hom.; ἱππικῶν ὠκύπους ἀγών Soph.; κύνες Eur., etc.

div1.head: ὠκύπτερος
div1.sense: swift-winged, Il.
ὠκύπτερα, ων, τά, the long quill-feathers in a wing, Ar.

div1.head: ὠκύροος
div1.sense: poet. adj. swift-flowing, Il.

div1.head: ὠκύσκοπος
div1.sense: quick-aiming, Ἀπόλλων Anth.

div1.head: ὠκύς
div1.sense: quick, swift, fleet, Od.; πόδας ὠκύς, of Achilles, Il.; πόδας ὠκέα, of Iris, Il., etc.
= ὀξύς, sharp, Anth.
adv. -έως, Pind.; but in form ὦκα, formed like τάχα, often in Hom.
degrees of Comparison, regul. ὠκύτερος, ὠκύτατος Od.: irreg. Sup., ὤκιστος Il., Aesch.

div1.head: ὠκύτης
div1.sense: quickness, swiftness, fleetness, speed, Pind., Eur.

div1.head: ὠκύτοκος
div1.sense: quickly born:— as Subst., ὠκύτοκον, ου, quick birth, easy delivery, Hdt.

div1.head: ὠκυτόκος
div1.sense: causing quick and easy birth: metaph. of a river, with quickening, fertilising power, Soph.

div1.head: ὠλέκρανον
div1.sense: the point of the elbow, Arist.

div1.head: ὠλένη
div1.sense: Lat. ulna, the elbow, or rather the arm from the elbow downwards, Hhymn., Trag., etc.; περὶ ὠλένας δέρᾳ βάλλειν Eur.; ὠλ. ἄκραι the hands, Eur.; ψήφους διηρίθμησε ὠλένῃ with the hand, Eur.

div1.head: Ὤλενος
div1.sense: Olenos, a city of Achaia, Il.; prob. named from its lying in the bend (ὠλένη) of a hill.

div1.head: ὠλεσίβωλος
div1.sense: clod-crushing, Anth.

div1.head: ὠλεσίκαρπος
div1.sense: losing its fruit, ἰτέαι ὠλ., because these trees shed their fruits before ripening, Od.

div1.head: ὠλεσίοικος
div1.sense: destroying the house, Aesch.

div1.head: ὦλξ
div1.sense: a furrow, only in acc. ὦλκα, ὦλκας, Hom., Mosch.

div1.head: ὠμαχθής
div1.sense: heavy to the shoulders, Anth.

div1.head: ὠμηστής
div1.sense: eating raw flesh, Il., Aesch., Soph., etc.; with a fem., Ἔχιδνα ὠμηστής Hes.:—as a mark of savageness, brutality, ὠμ. καὶ ἄπιστος ἀνήρ Il.

div1.head: ὠμοβόειος
div1.note: ὠμο-βόειος, Ionic -βόεος, or ὠμοβόϊνος, η, ον
div1.sense: of raw, untanned ox-hide, Hdt., Xen.:— ἡ ὠμοβοέη (sc. δορά) a raw ox-hide, Hdt.

div1.head: ὠμοβρώς
div1.sense: eating raw flesh, Eur.

div1.head: ὠμογέρων
div1.sense: a fresh, active old man, Il.

div1.head: ὠμοδακής
div1.sense: fiercely gnawing, Aesch.

div1.head: ὠμόδροπος
div1.sense: plucked unripe, νόμιμα ὠμ., properly, the right of plucking the fresh fruit, Aesch.

div1.head: ὠμοθετέω
div1.sense: in sacrificing, to place the raw slices duly on the altar (v. μηρία), Hom.:—so in Mid., ὠμοθετεῖτο Od.

div1.head: ὤμοι
div1.sense: ὦ μοι, Lat. hei mihi, woeʼs me, Soph.

div1.head: ὠμοκρατής
div1.sense: of rude untamed might, or (ὦμος) strong-shouldered, Soph.

div1.head: ὠμοπλάτη
div1.sense: the shoulder-blade, Theocr.; mostly in pl. ὠμοπλάται, Lat. scapulae, Xen., etc.

div1.head: ὠμόσιτος
div1.sense: of the Sphinx, eating men raw, Aesch.; χηλαῖσιν ὠμοσίτοις, also of the Sphinx, Eur.

div1.head: ὠμοσπάρακτος
div1.sense: torn in pieces raw, Ar.

div1.head: ὠμός
div1.sense: raw, undressed, Lat. crudus, of flesh, Hom.; ὠμὸν καταφαγεῖν τινά to eat one raw, proverb. of savage cruelty, Xen.; so, ὠμὸν βεβρώθοις Πρίαμον Il.
of fruit, unripe, Ar., Xen.
metaph. savage, fierce, cruel, Trag., Thuc., etc.:—neut. pl. ὠμά, as adv., savagely, Il.; adv. ὠμῶς, Thuc., etc.; Sup., ὠμότατα διακεῖσθαι πρός τινα Isocr.
rude, rough, Soph.; ὠμότερος συκοφάντης a more coarse, more unmitigated sycophant, Dem.:—adv. rudely, coarsely, Dem.
(from 1. 2) ὠμὸν γῆρας an unripe, untimely, premature old age, Od., Hes.

div1.head: ὦμος
div1.sense: Lat. humerus, the shoulder with the upper arm (ὠλένη, ulna, being the lower), ἐπʼ ὤμου φέρειν Od.; ὤμοισι φορέειν Il.; ἔχειν ἀνὰ ὤμῳ Od.; ὤμοισι τοῖς ἐμοῖσι "by the strength of mine arms, " Hdt.; ἀποστρέφειν τὸν ὦ. to dislocate it, Ar.
also of animals, as of a horse, Lat. armus, Il., Xen.

div1.head: ὠμότης
div1.sense: rawness: metaph. savageness, fierceness, cruelty, Eur., Xen., etc.

div1.head: ὠμοτόκος
div1.sense: bringing forth untimely offspring:— metaph. of a vine, Anth.

div1.head: ὠμοφάγος
div1.sense: eating raw flesh, carnivorous, Il., Thuc.

div1.head: ὠμόφρων
div1.sense: savage-minded, savage, Trag. adv. ὠμοφρόνως, Aesch.

div1.head: ὠνέομαι
div1.etym: aor1 is very dubious (for the Attic aorist is ἐπριάμην)
div1.sense: Mid.:— to buy, purchase, opp. to πωλέω, πιπράσκω, as Lat. emere to vendere; but in pres. and imperf. to offer to buy, deal for, bargain or bid for a thing, Hes.; ὠνέεσθαι τῶν φορτίων wished to buy some of their wares, began to bargain for them, Hdt.; Κροῖσός σφι ὠνεομένοισι ἔδωκε gave it them when they offered to buy, Hdt.; ὠν. τι παρά τινος from another, Hdt.; ὠν. ἐκ Κορίνθου to buy goods from Corinth, Xen.:—c. gen. pretii, to buy for so much, Hdt., Attic:—absol. in partic., ὠνούμενος by purchase, Xen.; ὁ ὠνούμενος the purchaser, Xen.; ὁ ἐωνημένος the owner by purchase of a slave, Ar.
to farm public taxes or tolls, or rather to bid for them, ὠν. μέταλλα Dem., etc.
to buy off, avert by giving hush-money, Dem.; ὠν. τινα to buy a person, of one who bribes, Dem.
sometimes used as Pass. to be bought, as ὠνούμενά τε καὶ πιπρασκόμενα Plat.; perf. part. ἐωνημένος Plat., Dem.; 3 sg. plup. ἐώνητο Ar.; in aor1 ἐωνήθην Xen.

div1.head: ὠνή
div1.sense: a buying, purchasing, Lat. emptio, ὠνὴ καὶ πρᾶσις buying and selling, Hdt., Plat.
a purchase, a bargain, Eur.
a contract for the farming of taxes, Andoc., Plut.
the purchase-money, price, Lys., Plut.

div1.head: ὠνητέος
div1.sense: to be bought, Plat.
ὠνητέον, one must buy, Luc.

div1.head: ὠνητής
div1.sense: a buyer, purchaser, Xen., Aeschin.

div1.head: ὠνητός
div1.sense: bought, of slaves, Od., Soph., etc.; ὠνητὴ δύναμις a mercenary force, opp. to οἰκεία, Thuc.
to be bought, that may be bought, Lat. venalis, ἐλπίς Eur.; c. gen. pretii, δόξα χρημάτων οὐκ ὠνητή not to be bought for money, Isocr.; but, χρήμασιν with money, Thuc.

div1.head: ὤνιος
div1.sense: to be bought, for sale, Lat. venalis, πῶς ὁ σῖτος ὤνιος; howʼs corn selling? Ar.; ἐς ὤνιον ἐλθεῖν to come to market, Theogn.; ὤνιον εἶναι to be on sale, Plat.:— τὰ ὤνια goods for sale, market-wares, Xen., etc.:—c. gen. pretii, αἵματος ἡ ἀρετὴ ὠνία Aeschin.
venal, of a magistrate, Arist.

div1.head: ὠνομασμένως
div1.etym: adverb from part. perf. pass. of ὀνομάζω
div1.sense: by giving names, Arist.

div1.head: ὦνος
div1.sense: Lat. venum, purchase-money, a price, sum paid for a thing, Hom.; c. gen. rei, Λυκάονος ὦνον ἔδωκεν for Lycaon, Il.
purchase, Od.

div1.head: ᾠόν
div1.sense: Lat. ovum, an egg, Attic
of the eggs or spawn of fish, Hdt.

div1.head: ὠόπ
div1.sense: ὤοπ also ὠὸπ ὄπ, a cry of the κελευστής to make the rowers stop pulling, avast! Ar.

div1.head: ὦ
div1.sense: and ὤ, Exclamation, expressing surprise, but also joy and pain, like our O! oh! with nom., ὢ τάλας ἐγώ Soph., etc.; with gen., ὢ χρυσῶ Theocr.
with vocat. it is a mere address, ὦ θεοί, ὦ Ζεῦ, etc.; with imperat., ὦ χαῖρε Aesch.—In the first sense it is usually written ὤ, in the second ὦ.

div1.head: ω
div1.sense: Ω, ω, ὦ μέγα, twenty-fourth letter of the Gr. alphabet: —as a numeral ωʹ 800, but ͵ω = 800, 000. The name of ὦ μέγα, great or long ο, was given at a later period to distinguish it from ὂ μικρόν little or short ο· but the form Ω was not adopted at Athens till the Archonship of Euclides (B. C. 403); v. sub E, H. Changes of ω, esp. in the dialects:
Ionic sometimes for α, as ὤνθρωπος ὤριστος for ἄνθρωπος ἄριστος.
Ionic also for αυ, as θῶμα τρῶμα for θαῦμα τραῦμα:—this is also Doric, ὦλαξ for αὖλαξ.
Aeolic and Doric ω for ου, as ὠρανός Μῶσα κῶρος λιπῶσα for οὐρανός Μοῦσα κοῦρος λιποῦσα; so, ου and ους in gen. sg. and acc. pl. of 2nd decl. pass into ω and ως.
Doric, ω becomes ᾱ, as πρῶτος πρώτιστος θεωρός become πρᾶτος πράτιστος θεᾱρός; so gen. pl. of 1st dec. -ῶν becomes -ᾶν.
Aeol. sometimes also υ, as χελύνη for χελώνη.

div1.head: ὧπερ
div1.sense: where, Theocr.

div1.head: ὡραῖος
div1.sense: produced at the right season (ὥρα) , seasonable, timely: esp. of fruits, like Lat. hornus (from hora), βίος or βίοτος ὡρ. store of fruits gathered in due season, Hes.; ὡρ. καρποί the fruits of the season, Hdt.; so ὡραῖα, ων, τά, Thuc., Xen.:—also of animals, ὡρ. ἄρνες yearling lambs, Anth.
ἡ ὡραία, like ὥρα 1. 2, the summer season, esp. the months during which the troops kept the field, Dem.; —but also, τὴν μὲν ὡραίην οὐχ ὕει it does not rain in the season (sc. of rain), Hdt.
happening or done in season, in due season, seasonable, ἄροτος, ἔργον Hes.; ὡραῖόν ἐστι the weather is fair, Plut.
metaph. seasonable, due, proper, ὡραῖα ἱερά Plat.
of persons, seasonable or ripe for a thing, c. gen., γάμων or γάμου ὡραίη Hdt.; ἐς ἥβην ὡρ. γάμων Eur.: —of old persons, ripe for death, πατήρ γε μὴν ὡραῖος Eur.; ὡραίῳ ἕσταμεν βίῳ Eur.
in the bloom of youth, blooming, Hes., Xen.:—generally, beautiful, NTest.

div1.head: ὡραιότης
div1.sense: ripeness of fruits, Arist.
the bloom of youth, Xen.

div1.head: ὡρακιάω
div1.sense: to faint, swoon away, Ar.

div1.head: ὥρα
div1.sense: Lat. hora: any time or period, whether of the year, month, or day (νυκτός τε ὥραν καὶ μηνὸς καὶ ἐνιαυτοῦ Xen.): hence

a part of the year, a season; in pl. the seasons, Od., Hes., etc.; περιτελλομέναις ὥραις Soph.; τῆς ὥρας τοῦ ἐνιαυτοῦ Thuc.:—at first three seasons were distinguished — spring, ἔαρος ὥρη, ὥρη εἰαρινή Hom.;— summer, θέρεος ὥρη Hes.; ὥρα θερινή Xen.;— winter, χείματος ὥρη Hes.; ὥρῃ χειμερίῃ Od.;—a fourth, ὀπώρα, first in Alcman.
absol. the prime of the year, springtime, ὅσα φύλλα γίγνεται ὥρῃ Hom.:—in historians, the part of the year available for war, the summer-season, or (as we say) the season, Thuc., etc.
the year generally, Hdt.; ἐν τῇ πέρυσιν ὥρᾳ last year, Dem., etc.
in pl. the quarters of the heavens, the summer being taken as south, winter as north, Hdt.
a part of the day, αἱ ὧραι τῆς ἡμέρας the times of day, i. e. morning, noon, evening, night, Xen.; also, νυκτὸς ἐν ὥρῃ in night time, Hhymn.; ὀψὲ τῆς ὥρας late in the day, Dem.

day and night were prob. first divided into twenty-four hours by Hipparchus (about 150 B. C.): but the division of the natural day (from sunrise to sunset) into twelve parts is mentioned by Hdt. (2. 109).
the time or season for a thing, ὅταν ὥ. ἥκῃ Xen., etc.
c. gen. rei, ὥρη κοίτοιο, ὕπνου the time for sleep, bed- time, Od.; ὥρη δόρποιο Od.; καρπῶν ὧραι Ar.
ὥρα ἐστίν, c. inf., ʼtis time to do a thing, ἀλλὰ καὶ ὥρη εὕδειν Od.; δοκεῖ οὐχ ὥρα εἶναι καθεύδειν Xen., etc.

in adverb. usages, τὴν ὥρην at the right time, Hdt., Xen.; but, τὴν ὥ. at that hour, Hes.:— ἐν ὥρῃ in due time, in good time, Od., Ar.:—also, αἰεὶ ἐς ὥρας in successive seasons, Od.;— καθʼ ὥραν Theocr.;— πρὸ τῆς ὥρας Xen.
metaph. the prime of life, youth, early manhood, ὥραν ἔχειν Aesch.; πάντες οἱ ἐν ὥρᾳ Plat., etc.; φεῦ φεῦ τῆς ὥρας. τοῦ κάλλους. ah! what youth! what beauty! Ar., etc.
= τὰ ὡραῖα, the fruits of the year, Xen.

in mythol. sense, αἱ Ὧραι, the Hours, keepers of heavenʼs gate, Il.; and ministers of the gods, Il.; three in number, daughters of Zeus and Themis, Hes.; often therefore joined with the Χάριτες, Hhymn., Hes.

div1.head: ὤρα
div1.sense: care, concern, heed, regard for a person or thing, c. gen., Hes., Soph.; μηδεμίαν ὤρην ἔχειν γυναικῶν Hdt.

div1.head: ὥρασι
div1.sense: in season, in good time, Ar.

div1.head: ὠρείτροφος
div1.sense: of Bacchus, Anth.

div1.head: ὠρεσίδουπος
div1.sense: making a din on the mountains, Anth.

div1.head: ὡρεσιδώτης
div1.sense: one who gives ripe fruits in their season, Anth.

div1.head: ὠρεύω
div1.sense: to attend to, mind, c. acc., Hes.

div1.head: ὡρηφόρος
div1.sense: leading on the seasons, or bringing on the fruits in season, Hhymn.

div1.head: ὡρικός
div1.sense: in oneʼs prime, youthful, blooming, Ar.: adv., ὡρικῶς πυνθάνει you ask so maidenly, so prettily, Ar.

div1.head: ὥριμος
div1.sense: ripe, Anth.

div1.head: ὥριος
div1.sense: produced in season, ὥρια the fruits of the season, Od., Theocr.
generally, in due season, seasonable, Hes., Anth.
ὥρια, ων, τά, the season, νόσον ὥρια τίκτει Bion.

div1.head: Ὠρίων
div1.sense: Orion, one of the giants, a mighty hunter, loved by Aurora, slain by Artemis, Od.
a bright constellation named after him, which rose just after the summer solstice, and was usually followed by storms, Hom.

div1.head: ὡροθετέω
div1.sense: to take note of a thing in casting a nativity, Anth.
to be in the ascendant at the natal hour, of oneʼs ruling planet, Anth.

trans.i: one who takes note of times.

div1.head: ὡρόμαντις
div1.sense: the hour-prophet, of the cock, Babr.

div1.head: ὡρονομέω
div1.sense: to rule the hour of birth, of planets, Anth.

div1.head: ὧρος
div1.sense: a year:—in pl. annals, Luc.

div1.head: ὦρος
div1.sense: a mountain, Theocr.

div1.head: ὠρυθμός
div1.sense: a howling, roaring, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: ὠρύομαι
div1.sense: Med. to howl, properly of wolves and dogs, Theocr., etc.:—of men, ὄρθιον ὤρυσαι Pind.; of savages, either in mourning or joy, Hdt.
trans. to howl over, τῆνον μὲν θῶες, τῆνον λύκοι ὤρυσαντο Theocr.; so, ὠρ. ἐπί τινι Luc.; περί τινα Bion.

div1.head: ὡσάν
div1.sense: Epic ὥς κε or ὥς κεν, being ὡς with a conditional force added.
as if, as it were, Dem., NTest.

div1.head: ὡσαύτως
div1.sense: in like manner, just so, ὣς δʼ αὔτως, for ὡσαύτως δὲ . . , Hom., etc.; ὡσαύτως καὶ . . in like manner as . . , Hdt.; so c. dat., ὣς δʼ αὔτως τῇσι κυσὶ θάπτονται Hdt.; ὡσ. ἔχειν Plat.

div1.head: ὡσεί
div1.sense: just as if, as though, ἐφίλησʼ ὡς εἴ τε πατὴρ ὃν παῖδα φιλήσῃ Il.
like ὡς E, with Numerals, about, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: ὡς
div1.sense: A. ADVERB of Manner, either ὥς (with accent) Demonstr. so, thus, Lat. sic;— or ὡς (without accent) Relat. as, Lat. ut. B. ὡς, as CONJUNCTION. C, D. various usages.
of Manner:
ὥς, Demonstr. = οὕτως, so, thus, Lat. sic, Hom., Hdt.; rare in Attic:— καὶ ὥς, even so, nevertheless, οὐδʼ ὥς, μηδʼ ὥς, not even so, in no wise, Hom., Soph.
in Comparisons, ὥς . . , ὡς . . , so . . as . . , Lat. sic . . ut . . , Il., Plat.
thus, for instance, Od.

ὡς, Relat., as, Lat. ut, first in Hom.; οὕτως ὡς, Lat. sic ut; but the antec. is often omitted: similes are commonly introduced by ὡς ὅτε, ὡς δʼ ὅτε, where ὅτε often seems superfluous, ἤριπε δʼ, ὡς ὅτε πύργος ἤριπε Il.:—this ὡς takes the accent at the end of a clause or when it follows the word dependent on it; θεὸς δʼ ὣς τίετο δήμῳ Il.; οἱ δὲ φέβοντο, βόες ὥς Od.
according as, where the relat. Pron. ὅσος might stand, as ἑλὼν κρέας ὥς (i. e. ὅσον) οἱ χεῖρες ἐχάνδανον Od.; σοὶ θεοὶ πόροιεν ὡς ἐγὼ θέλω Soph.

parenthetically, to qualify a general statement, ὡς ἐμοὶ δοκεῖ, ὡς ἔοικε, etc., as it seems; often with γε or γοῦν added, ὡς γοῦν as at any rate:—these phrases become elliptical, ὡς ἐμοί or ὥς γʼ ἐμοί (sc. δοκεῖ) ; ὡς ἀπ’ ὀμμάτων (sc. εἰκάσαι) to judge by eyesight, Soph.;—also, ὡς Λακεδαιμόνιος (sc. ὤν) considering he was a Lacedaemonian, Thuc.; ὡς γυνή as a woman, like a very woman, Soph.: —so ὡς is attached to the Object of the Verb, συμπέμψας αὐτὸν ὡς φύλακα (sc. εἶναι) having sent him with them as a guard, Hdt.; ὡς ἐπὶ φρυγανισμόν as if for collecting fuel, Thuc.

to limit or augment the force of Adverbs: ὡς ἀληθῶς as of a truth, i. e. in very truth, Plat.; also after Adverbs expressing anything extraordinary, θαυμαστῶς or θαυμασίως ὡς, ὑπερφυῶς ὡς, v. sub vocc.:—also with the Sup., like ὅ τι and ὅπως, ὡς μάλιστα, Lat. quam maxime, ὡς ῥᾷστα, quam facillime; ὡς τάχιστα, quam celerrime, Hdt., etc.:—in the phrases ὡς τὸ πολύ, ὡς ἐπὶ τὸ πολύ Plat.; ὡς ἐπὶ τὸ πλῆθος Plat.
so also with Adjs., ὅπως ὡς βέλτισται ἔσονται Plat.; ὡς ἐς ἐλάχιστον Thuc.
ὡς, as CONJUNCTION:
with Substantive Clauses, for ὅτι, Lat. quod, that, expressing a fact, μηκέτʼ ἐκφοβοῦ, ὥς σε ἀτιμάσει Soph., etc.

ὡς with Final Clauses, that, in order that, Lat. ut; ὡς, and ὡς ἄν, Epic ὥς κεν, being used, like other Final Conjunctions, with the subj. after the principal tenses of the ind., and with the opt. after the past tenses: cf. ἵνα B, ὅπως B.
with past tenses of the ind. to express an event that is past, and therefore impossible, τί μʼ οὐκ ἔκτεινας, ὡς ἔδειξα μήποτε . . ; so that I never should . . , Soph.
ὡς c. inf., to limit an assertion, ὡς εἰπεῖν so to say, Lat. ut ita dicam, Hdt.; ὡς ἔπος εἰπεῖν, etc.; ὡς εἰκάσαι to make a guess, i. e. probably, Hdt.
just like ὥστε c. inf., so that, Lat. adeo ut, ita ut, εὖρος ὡς δύο τριήρεας πλέειν ὁμοῦ in breadth such that two triremes could sail abreast, Hdt.
ἢ ὡς after a comp., μάσσονʼ ἢ ὡς ἰδέμεν Pind.; μαλακώτεροι, ἢ ὡς κάλλιον Plat.
Causal, like ὅτι or ἐπεί, as, inasmuch, as, since, Lat. quia, quandoquidem, τί ποτε λέγεις; ὡς οὐ μανθάνω Soph.
Temporal, for ὅτε, ἐπεί, when, Lat. ut, ἐνῶρτο γέλως, ὡς ἴδον laughter arose among them, when they saw, Il.; with opt., to express a repeated action, whenever, ὡς ἀπίκοιτο Hdt.
ὡς seems to be used for ἕως or ἔστε, so long as, while, ὡς ἂν αὑτὸς ἥλιος αἴρῃ Soph.:—in later Gr. = ἕως, while, NTest.

= ὅπως, how, like Lat. ut for quomodo, μερμήριζε, ὡς Ἀχιλῆα τιμήσειε Il.;—so, οὐκ ἔσθʼ ὡς nowise can it be that, Soph.; οἶσθʼ ὡς ποίησον, by a mixture of constructions for ὡς χρὴ ποιῆσαι, Soph.; v. *εἴδω B. 5.
ὡς ἂν ποιήσῃς however thou mayʼst act, Soph.
Local, for ὅπου, where, Theocr.
some special usages:
with Participles, to give the reason or motive of the action expressed by the Verb, if, as, διαβαίνει, ὡς ἀμήσων τὸν σῖτον Hdt.
with Participles in the case of the Object, λέγουσιν ἡμᾶς ὡς ὀλωλότας they speak of us as dead, Aesch.
with Participles put absolutely, ἐρώτα ὅ τι βούλει, ὡς τἀληθῆ ἐροῦντος (i. e. πιστεύων με ἐρεῖν) Xen., etc.
so also before Prepositions, ἀνήγοντο ὡς ἐπὶ ναυμαχίαν (i. e. ὡς ναυμαχήσοντες) Thuc.; πλεῖς ὡς πρὸς οἶκον Soph.; ὡς ἐκ κακῶν ἐχάρη Hdt.

the Preps. εἰς, ἐπί, came to be omitted, and ὡς itself appears to be used as a prep. c. acc., but only c. acc. pers., τὸν ὅμοιον ἄγει θεὸς ὡς τὸν ὅμοιον god brings like to like, Od.; ὡς Ἆγιν ἐπρεσβεύσαντο Thuc.
ὡς, before independent sentences:
ὡς as an emphatic exclamation, how, as Lat. ut for quam, ὡς ἄνοον κραδίην ἔχες how silly a heart hadst thou! Il.; ὡς ἀγαθόν Od.; ὡς ἀστεῖος ὁ ἄνθρωπος how charming he is! Plat.
when it is joined to a Verb, its force extends to the whole sentence, ὥς ὑπερδέδοικά σου how greatly do I fear for thee, Soph.

it also denotes a quick succession of events, ὡς ἴδεν, ὥς μιν Ἔρως φρένας ἀμφεκάλυψεν how he saw, how did Love encompass his heart, i. e. he saw and straightway Love . . , Il.; ὡς ἴδον, ὡς ἐμάνην, ὥς μευ περὶ θυμὸς ἰάφθη Theocr.; (so Virgil ut vidi, ut perii, ut me malus abstulit error).
ὡς to express a wish, like εἴθε, Lat. utinam, oh that! with the opt. ὡς ἀπόλοιτο καὶ ἄλλος Od.; ὡς μὴ θάνοι oh that he might not die! Od.
ὡς joined with other words of wishing, ὡς ὤφελες αὐτόθʼ ὀλέσθαι Il.; ὡς δὴ μὴ ὄφελον νικᾶν Od.
ὡς with Numerals marks that they are to be taken only as a round number, as it were, about, nearly, σὺν ἀνθρώποις ὡς εἴκοσι Xen.; παῖς ὡς ἑπταετής some seven years old, Plat.
ὡς in some Elliptical Phrases:
ὡς τί (sc. γένηται) ; to what end? Eur.
ὡς ἕκαστος each separately, Lat. pro se quisque, Hdt., Thuc.
Etymology: ὡς is an adv. form of the relat. ὅς, as τώς of ὁ, οὕτως of οὗτος.

div1.head: ὥς
div1.sense: adverb of Manner, like as, even as, just as, ἀλώμενος ὥσπερ Ὀδύσσευς Od., etc.;—Hom. often puts a word between ὡς and περ, e. g. ὡς σύ περ αὐτή, ὡς τοπάρος περ, ὡς ἔσεταί περ; ὥσπερ εἶχον just as they were, then and there, Hdt.; εὐθὺς ὥσπερ εἶχεν Xen.;—strengthd., ὥσπερ γε exactly as, Ar.; ὁμοίως, ὥσπερ Thuc.
to limit or modify an assertion, like ὡσπερεί, as it were, Lat. tanquam, ὥσπερ ἐγγελῶσα Soph.
of Time, as soon as, Ar.

div1.head: ὡσπεροὖν
div1.sense: even as, just as, ὥσπερ οὖν ἀπώλετο Aesch.
as indeed, as no doubt, εἰ δ’ ἔστιν (ὥσπερ οὖν ἔστι) θεός Plat.

div1.head: ὥσπερ
div1.sense: just as if, even as, Lat. quasi, tanquam, ὥσπερ εἰ παρεστάτεις Aesch., ὥσπερ τις μηδὲν διδοίη Soph.
ὥσπερ ἂν εἰ or ὡσπερανεί (which properly is elliptical for ὥσπερ ἂν ἦν, εἰ . .) , Plat.

div1.head: ὥστε
div1.sense: as adv., bearing the same relation to ὡς, as ὅστε to ὅς, and used by Hom. more frequently than ὡς in similes; rare in Attic Poets, κατώρυχες δʼ ἔναιον ὥστʼ ἀήσυροι μύρμηκες Aesch., etc.
as, as being, like ἅτε, Lat. utpote, ῥεῖα μάλʼ, ὥστε θεός very easily, as being a goddess, Il.; ὥστε περὶ ψυχῆς since it was for life, Od.; ὥστε ταῦτα νομίζων Hdt.
as Conjunction, to express the result or effect of the action in the principal clause:
with Inf. so as to do a thing, εἰ δέ σοι θυμὸς ἐπέσσυται, ὥστε νέεσθαι if thy heart is bent upon returning, Il.; οὐ τηλίκος, ὥστε πιθέσθαι not of such age as to obey, Od.; freq. in Attic

after Comparatives with ἤ, when the possibility of the consequence is denied, μέζω κακὰ ἢ ὥστε ἀνακλαίειν greater woes than that one is wont to weep for, i. e. too great for tears, Hdt.; μεῖζον ἢ ὥστε φέρειν δύνασθαι κακόν Xen.:—the Posit. is sometimes put for the comp., ψυχρὸν ὥστε λούσασθαι (for ψυχρότερον ἢ ὥστε . .) too cold to bathe in, Xen.
on the condition that . . , like ἐφʼ ᾧτε, παραδοῦναι σφᾶς αὐτοὺς Ἀθηναίοις, ὥστε βουλεῦσαι ὅ τι ἂν ἐκείνοις δοκῇ Thuc.
with the Ind., to express the result with emphasis, οὐχ οὕτω φρενοβλαβέες, ὥστε ἐβούλοντο not so insane, as to wish, Hdt.; βέβηκεν, ὥστε πᾶν ἔξεστι φωνεῖν Soph., etc.
at the beginning of a sentence, to mark a strong conclusion, and so, therefore, consequently, ὥστʼ ὄλωλα καί σε προσδιαφθερῶ Soph.; with the Imperat., ὥστε μὴ λίαν στένε Soph.; ὥστε θάρρει Xen.
with part., for inf., by attraction to a participle in the principal clause, τοσοῦτον διενεγκόντες, ὥσθʼ ἐπιτάττοντες differing so much as to impose commands, Isocr.

div1.head: ὠστίζομαι
div1.sense: to push and be pushed about, mostly c. dat. pers., ὠστιεῖ Κλεονύμῳ you will justle with Cleonymus, Ar.; ὠστιοῦνται ἀλλήλοισι περὶ πρώτου ξύλου Ar.; absol., εἰς τὴν προεδρίαν πᾶς ἀνὴρ ὠστίζεται justles for the first seat, Ar.

div1.head: ὠτακουστέω
div1.sense: to hearken to, listen, watch covertly, Hdt., Xen., etc.

div1.head: ὠτακουστής
div1.sense: a listener, spy, Arist.

div1.head: ὠτάριον
div1.sense: a little ear, Anth.

div1.head: ὠτειλή
div1.sense: a wound just inflicted, δεῖξεν αἷμα κατάρρεον ἐξ ὠτειλῆς Il.; αἷμʼ ἔτι θερμὸν ἀνήνοθεν ἐξ ὠτ. Il.
the mark of a wound, a scar, Xen., Plut.

div1.head: ὠτίον
div1.etym: Dim. of οὖς, but often = οὖς, Anth., NTest.

div1.head: ὠτίς
div1.sense: a kind of bustard with long earfeathers, prob. the great bustard, Xen.

div1.head: ὠτώεις
div1.sense: poet. adj. with ears or handles, Il., Hes.

div1.head: ὠφέλεια
div1.note: ὠφέλεια, and ὠφελία, Ionic ὠφελίη, ἡ,
div1.sense: help, aid, succour, assistance, esp. in war, Thuc.; τὴν ὠφ. παρέχειν τινι Thuc.; ὠφελίας τυγχάνειν Thuc.; οὐ μετὰ τῶν κειμένων νόμων ὠφελίας not for such assistance as is consistent with the laws (ὠφελίας being = ὠφελίας ἕνεκα) Thuc.
utility, use, profit, advantage, benefit, Hdt., Soph.; c. gen. objecti, ἐπʼ ὠφελείᾳ τῶν φίλων for service to them, for their benefit, Plat.
a source of gain or profit, a benefit, service, Plat., etc.
spoil, booty, game, Xen., Plut.

div1.head: ὠφελέω
div1.sense: to help, aid, assist, succour, to be of use or service to any one:
absol. to be of use or service, τὰ μηδὲν ὠφελοῦντα Aesch.; οὐδὲν ὠφελεῖ Thuc.
mostly c. acc. pers., like Lat. juvare, to be of service to, to benefit, Hdt., Aesch., etc.; ὠφ. τινα ἔς τι to be of use to one towards a thing, Thuc.
more rarely c. dat. pers., like Lat. prodesse, Trag., Antipho.
once c. gen., οὐδεὶς ἔρωτος τοῦδʼ ἐφαίνετʼ ὠφελῶν no one appeared to help towards this desire, Soph.
c. acc. cogn., ὠφέλειαν ὠφ. τινα to render him a service, Plat.; so with a neut. adj., οὐδέν τινα ὠφ. to do one no service, Hdt. (v. supr. 1); πολλά, πλέον, πλεῖστον, ὡς πλεῖστα ὠφ. Eur., etc.

div1.head: ὠφέλημα
div1.sense: a useful or serviceable thing, a service, benefit, Aesch., Eur.
generally, use, advantage, profit, Soph., Xen.

div1.head: ὠφελήσιμος
div1.sense: useful, serviceable, Soph., Ar.

div1.head: ὠφέλησις
div1.sense: a helping, aiding; and so (generally) like ὠφέλεια, use, service, advantage, Soph.

div1.head: ὠφελητέος
div1.sense: necessary or proper to be assisted, Xen.
ὠφελητέον, one must assist, τὴν πόλιν Xen.

div1.head: ὠφέλιμος
div1.sense: helping, useful, serviceable, profitable, advantageous, beneficial, of persons and things, Thuc., Plat., etc.; τινι to on Eur., etc.; ἔς τι for a purpose, Thuc.; πρός τι Plat.; —τὸ ὠφ. as Subst., Plat.:—adv. -μως, Xen.; Sup. -ώτατα, Xen.

div1.head: ὠχράω
div1.sense: to turn pale or wan, ὠχρᾶν χρόα to be wan of countenance, Od.

div1.head: ὠχριάω
div1.sense: to be pallid, Ar., Arist.

div1.head: ὦχρος
div1.sense: paleness, wanness, esp. the pale hue of fear, ὦχρος δέ μιν εἷλε παρειάς Il.

div1.head: ὠχρός
div1.sense: pale, wan, sallow, of complexion, Eur., Ar.; of a frog, Batr. :—τὸ ὠχρόν the colour yellow, Plat.

div1.head: ὠχρότης
div1.sense: paleness, Plat.

div1.head: ὤψ
div1.sense: the eye, face, countenance, Hom., Hes.; εἰς ὦπα ἰδέσθαι τινί to look one in the face, Il.; and absol., εἰς ὦπα ἰδέσθαι Od.; but, θεῇς εἰς ὦπα ἔοικεν in face she is like the goddesses, Il.
